My argument is simple: success and failure are the most objective metrics by which we can evaluate a hero's actions and their impact on society. It is only natural that we evaluate heroes based on the outcomes of their endeavors, as it provides a clear and accurate assessment of their character and abilities.

Furthermore, judging heroes by their successes and failures allows us to distinguish between true heroes and those who are merely pretending to be heroes. It is easy to claim to be a hero, but it is much harder to actually achieve heroic deeds. By measuring their achievements, we can separate the true heroes from the pretenders.

In addition, judging heroes by their successes and failures serves as a powerful motivator for heroes to strive for excellence. When heroes know that their actions will be judged based on their outcomes, they are more likely to push themselves to achieve greatness.

In conclusion, judging heroes by their successes and failures is not only a fair and objective way to evaluate them, but it also encourages heroes to strive for greatness and serves as a means to distinguish true heroes from those who are merely pretending to be heroes. Thank you.
